items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  8.02
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
FROM:
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Linda da Silva, Director of Construction, Maintenance and Facilities, André Bell, Director of Purchasing and Capital Accounting, Mariel Caballero, Chairperson, Joshua Barousse, Ramon Martinez, and Barry Schimmel of Measure G, Measure E, Measure I, and Technology Measure I Citizens’ Bond Oversight Committee
					 
SUBJECT:
Receive Citizens' Bond Oversight Committee’s 2013-2014 Bond Program Annual Report for Measures G, E and I
	 
	 
The Citizens’ Bond Oversight Committee (CBOC) has produced their Bond Program Annual Report for 2013-2014.  This Annual Report satisfies the requirement of Education Code Section 15278(a) for the Committee to inform the public concerning the expenditure of bond revenues, by actively reviewing and reporting on the proper expenditure of taxpayers’ money for school construction.  The Report will be distributed to the community in late August.
	 
The 2013-2014 Bond Program Annual Report will be presented to the Board by CBOC Chairperson Mariel Caballero, and members Joshua Barousse, Ramon Martinez, and Barry Schimmel.
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees receive the 2013 - 2014 Annual CBOC Report for Measures G, E, and I.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  8.03
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, and Karen Poon, Director of Finance
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Presentation, Discussion and/or Action Regarding 2015-16 Budget Updates
	 
The attached budget revisions are provided for budgetary planning purposes only and are not provided pursuant to AB1200, which allows school districts to post revisions to their adopted budget within 45 days of the Governor’s signature on the State budget.  On June 25, 2015, the Governor signed the 2015-16 Budget Act, which includes the Legislature’s initial Budget Act (AB 93), a second Budget Act bill (SB 97) that amends the initial Budget Act, and a number of “trailer bills” that include additional appropriations and changes in statutory language related to program details.  The Governor’s Final Budget include the following changes from his May revision:  
	 
STATE REVENUES 
	 
Local Control Funding Formula (LCFF) (GAP %)
The final budget provides $5.994 billion towards the implementation of LCFF. This amount is slightly less than the $6.1 billion proposed in the Governor’s May Revision. This appropriation reduces the funding gap for district LCFF targets to 51.5 percent from 53.08%.  East Side’s LCFF funding is expected to decrease by $1.89 million through fiscal year 2017-18.  
	 
One-time Discretionary Funding 
The final Budget Act provides $3.2 billion or $530 per ADA for K-12 school districts. This amount is slightly less than the $3.5 billion or $601 per ADA provided in the Governor’s May revision.  The outstanding mandate repayment backlog now stands to be $1.5 billion ($1.2 billion for schools and about $300 million for community colleges). The final budget indicates that these are one-time funds that can be used at the discretion of local school districts.  Fiscal year 2015-16 one-time discretionary revenues for ESUHSD are expected to decline by $1.604 million.   
	 
Lottery 
The original projection for unrestricted lottery at the May revision was $128 per ADA.  With the elimination of the Adult Education and Regional Occupational Center/Program ADA as part of the State lottery formula, the Lottery projected funding for 2015-16 is now projected at $181 per ADA ($140 unrestricted and $41 Proposition 20).  Unrestricted lottery funding for ESUHSD is expected to increase by $826 thousand through fiscal year 2017-18. 
	 
Educator Effectiveness (Restricted Dollars)  
The budget provides $500 million to school districts for the purpose of increasing the effectiveness of instructional staff and school leadership.  The dollars are to be used for beginning teacher and administrator support and mentoring; professional development, coaching, and support services for teachers who have been identified as needing improvement or additional support; professional development for teachers and administrators that is aligned to the State academic content standards; Promote educator quality and effectiveness, including, but not limited to; training on mentoring and coaching certificated staff and training certificated staff to support effective teaching and learning.  ESUHSD is projecting $1.7 million for the Teacher Effectiveness initiative, which are designated as restricted funds.  
	 
Routine Restricted Maintenance 
The Governor’s final budget permits through 2019-20 a phase-in of school district contributions to routine restricted maintenance accounts (no less than 2 percent by 2017-18 and 3 percent by 2020-21) and allows funds to be used for drought mitigation purposes.  The Adopted Budget for East Side allocates 3 percent, beginning in FY 2015-16 through FY 2017-18.  The District has the option to cap routine restricted maintenance dollars at the current 2015-16 level.  
	 
EXPENSES 
In relation to expenses, there were some major increases in the District’s expenses.  At Budget Adoption, the Board approved the addition of 4.625 FTE custodians for a total increase of $1 million through fiscal year 2017-18.  The District also recently received a special education disproportionately ruling, which will increase the fiscal year 2015-16 budget by an estimated $589,676.  The District’s health benefits consultant Gallagher and Company recently notified the District that we should budget for increased expenditures totaling $850,000 in fiscal year 2017-18 due to the Cadillac tax provision within the Affordable Care Act, which goes into effect on January 1, 2018.   Lastly, Educational Services Division has requested a $200,000 budget augmentation to pilot textbooks in fiscal year 2015-16.  The total increase in expenditures for the multi-year period between fiscal year 2015-16 through fiscal year 2017-18 totals $2.56 million in the unrestricted General Fund.  
	 
Summary  
In summary, the net effect on the District’s unrestricted General Fund Revenues totals a net loss of $2.6 million.  Total expenses are expected to increase by $2.56 million.  Overall, the District’s unrestricted financial reserves are projected to decline from 9.66% to 7.73% by fiscal year 2017-18 as a result of the budget revisions noted.   
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees accept the budget revisions to the 2015-16 adopted budget for budgetary planning purposes only.

EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
		 
Item:  9.01
		 
		 
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
					 
FROM:
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Linda da Silva, Director of Construction, Maintenance and Facilities, André Bell, Director of Purchasing and Capital Accounting, and Janice Unger, Capital Projects Purchasing Manager
					 
					 
SUBJECT:
Hold Public Hearing at Approximately 6:05 p.m. for District Wide Energy Efficiency Project and Proposed District Wide Energy Services Contract (Government Code Section 4217.10 - 4217.18)
		 
The Board of Trustees of the East Side Union High School District will hold a public hearing regarding a proposed District Wide Energy Services Contract to provide energy conservation and savings measures to the East Side Union High School District.
		 
The attached Public Notice of this Hearing was posted at the East Side Union High School District office, all district school sites, and published in the San Jose Post-Record (proof of publication included).

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
				 
Item:  09.02
				 
TO:
Board of Trustees
								 
FROM:  
								 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
							 
							 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Linda da Silva, Director of Construction, Maintenance and Facilities, André Bell, Director of Purchasing and Capital Accounting, and Janice Unger, Capital Projects Purchasing Manager
							 
							 
SUBJECT:
Adopt Resolution #2015/2016-01 Finding and Determining that the Anticipated Cost of Energy Conservation Measures will be Less than the Anticipated Marginal Cost to the District of Energy that would have been Consumed in the Absence of Those Purchases, Authorizing Execution of an Energy Services Contract with OpTerra Energy Services, and Approving Use of School Facilities Fund 35 to Bridge the Funding Gap Until Receipt of Proposition 39 Clean Energy Job Creation Fund and Utility Rebate Proceeds
				 
				 
On March 20, 2014, (Board item 9.06), following a competitive selection process based on qualifications and fee pricing, the Board of Trustees authorized the Associate Superintendent of Business Services to execute a Program Development Agreement with Chevron Energy Solutions Company (CES) to determine the specific energy conservation measures that will be used to support a proposed Energy Services Contract.  On September 1, 2014, CES was sold to OpTerra Energy Services and CES assigned its interest in the Program Development Agreement to OpTerra per the contract terms; OpTerra has assumed and is performing all the rights, duties, and obligations of the Program Development Agreement.  
				 
Since that time, OpTerra surveyed all District facilities, reviewed as-built construction records, analyzed electricity, gas, water and garbage utility records to ascertain usage and costs, investigated possible energy conservation measures, solicited preliminary pricing bids from a number of trades contractors, and met with District staff for information and direction.  Through this process, OpTerra developed a menu of energy saving measures, the cost of which will be outweighed by the energy savings provided through the improvements.
				 
The proposed package of improvements includes solar photovoltaic systems, interior and exterior lighting retrofits. 
				 
Government Code section 4217.10 – 4217.18 authorizes public agencies to enter into agreements with qualified energy services contract providers.  However, before awarding an energy services contract, the Governing Board must first determine and find in a public hearing that the net benefits of the energy conservation measures to be provided through the contract are greater than the expense of the contracted improvements.  The cost of OpTerra’s proposed scope package of energy savings measures is $5,225,711; the energy savings provided through the improvements is $8,125,770, on an unadjusted basis.  The energy savings outweigh the cost; therefore, this package of improvements is eligible to be awarded to OpTerra Energy Services through an energy services contract in accordance with Government Code section 4217.10 – 4217.18 (refer to Attachment A - 4217 Code Compliance Test).
				 
The scope package includes energy efficiency measures that are eligible for the Proposition 39 Clean Energy Jobs Act funds that have been and will continue to be allocated to the District, from fiscal years 2013-14 through 2017-18.  Administration anticipates Proposition 39 funding in the amount of $4.958 million.  The Proposition 39 program has a funding eligibility requirement of Savings-to-Investment Ratio (SIR) greater than 1.05. OpTerra has identified $5.2 million of eligible projects, with a  SIR of 1.11, which will qualify for Proposition 39 funds (refer to Attachment B “Proposition 39 Funding Eligibility Test”).  
				 
This Energy Services Contract includes a savings and performance guarantee of $6,214,498 over 15 years, as follows:
Solar kWh guaranteed by OpTerra for 15 years
Energy conservation savings guaranteed by OpTerra for 15 years
				 
In addition to the guaranteed energy savings the District will realize from this project, OpTerra’s proposal includes the following value-added benefits:
Improved indoor environmental comfort and function
Decreased disruption to learning and working environments due to equipment failures
Decreased maintenance burden
Economic stimulus through creation of 11 direct and over 100 indirect green construction jobs
Educational enrichment through internships and custom educational programming that supports Common Core implementation, enhances career pathways, and boosts professional development
Continuation of East Side’s leadership position in energy conservation
Environmental benefits of avoiding more than 2,305 metric tons of greenhouse gas emissions per year
				 
Funding for this initiative is as follows:
				 
Proposition 39 Clean Energy Jobs Creation           $  4,958,554 
Utility Rebates                                                        $      100,463
School Facilities Fund 35                                       $     166,694
Total               $  5,225,711
				 
				 
The California Clean Energy Jobs Act was created with the approval of Proposition 39 in the November 2012 statewide General Election.  Proposition 39 allocates projected revenue to the Clean Energy Job Creation Fund for five fiscal years, beginning with fiscal year 2013/14.  Allocations are made to schools and/or districts based on enrollment.  Applications for eligible projects are submitted to the California Energy Commission – the agency responsible for Proposition 39 oversight; upon completion of the approved projects, funds are disbursed.  OpTerra’s proposed scope package includes administering the applications, measurement and verification, and claims processes on the District’s behalf.  OpTerra will similarly administer utility rebate program applications, measurement and verification, and claims processes with PG&E.  Since Proposition 39 and utility rebate funds are not currently in hand, but will be secured in the coming months and through fiscal year 2017-18, the District will use School Facilities Fund 35 to bridge the funding gap until we receive Pro   position 39 and utility rebate proceeds.  The Proposition 39 funding allocations for fiscal years 2013-14 and 2014-15 are known and available as soon as the project is completed; the allocations are unknown for the following three years.  The funding amount indicated for Proposition 39 and the associated Fund 35 bridge funding are based on conservative projections.
				 
The terms of the Program Development Agreement between the District and OpTerra provide that OpTerra shall receive a $60,000 Assessment Fee for their work of the Program Development Phase; the terms further provide that if the District enters into an Energy Services Contract with OpTerra, this Assessment Fee shall be incorporated into the total contract amount payable under the Energy Services Contract (Attachment C).
				 
FISCAL IMPACT:
$5,225,711
				 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Proposition 39 Clean Energy Jobs Creation
$4,958,554 *
Board approved March 20, 2014, Board Item 9.06.
Funding is provided after energy measures are implemented, measured and verified.
*Note:  Projected total allocation in fiscal years 2013-14 through 2017-18.  The actual amount of Proposition 39 proceeds awarded in fiscal years 2015-16 through 2017-18 is not known at this time. 
Utility Rebates
$100,463
Funding is provided after energy measures are implemented, measured and verified.
School Facilities Fund 35
$5,225,711*
Fund 35 will be used to bridge the funding gap until the District receives Proposition 39 Clean Energy Jobs Creation and utility rebate proceeds.
*Note:  This amount is a projection.  The actual amount of Proposition 39 proceeds awarded in FY2015-16 through 2017-18 is not known at this time.  Amounts not reimbursed by Proposition 39 and Utility Rebate funds will be funded out of School Facilities Fund 35, projected to be $166,694.
				 
				 
				 
				 
				 
				 
				 
				 
				 
				 
				 
				 
				 
				 
				 
				 
				 
				 
				 
				 
				 
				 
				 
				 
				 
				 
				 
				 
				 
				 
				 
				 
				 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that, pursuant with Government Code section 4217.10 – 4217.18 and on the basis of the foregoing and the materials and analysis presented, the Board of Trustees adopt Resolution #2015-2016-01: (i) finding and determining that the anticipated cost to the District for thermal or electrical energy or conservation services provided by the energy conservation facility under the proposed contract with OpTerra will be less than the anticipated marginal cost to the District of thermal, electrical, or other energy that would have been consumed by the District in the absence of those purchases, (ii) authorizing the Associate Superintendent of Business Services to execute an Energy Services Contract with OpTerra Energy Services in an amount not to exceed $5,225,711, to provide energy saving measures, administer Proposition 39 Clean Energy Jobs Act and utility rebate funding processes, administer an associated educational enrichment program, and provide support and assistance with an energy conservation media campaign; and (iii) approving use of $5,225,711 of School Facilities Fund 35 to bridge the funding gap until the District receives Proposition 39 Clean Energy Job Creation fund and utility rebate proceeds, and to fund any small reimbursement gap, if any, with replenishment of Fund 35 with Proposition 39 and utility rebate funds as they are received.

EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
Item:  11.01
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Frank Biehl, Board Clerk
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action regarding California School Boards Association (CSBA) Candidate Nominations for Directors-at-Large:  African American, American Indian
	 
		 
The California School Boards Association (CSBA) is currently accepting nominations for Directors-at-Large:  African American and American Indian. The election will take place at CSBA's Delegate Assembly meeting in San Diego, California, on December 2-3, 2015.  Nominations for Directors-at-Large must be made by a CSBA board member and the nominee must be board member from a CSBA member district or county office of education.  Directors-at-Large serve a two-year term and take office immediately upon the close of the Association's Annual Education Conference in December.
		 
The Board is requested to submit nominations to CSBA for Directors-at-Large:  African American and American Indian
		 
		 
RECOMMENDATION:
		It is recommended that the Board of Trustees submit nominations to CSBA for Directors-at-Large: African American and American Indian

FROM:

PREPARED BY:
Glenn Vander Zee, Assistant Superintendent of Educational Services
						 
SUBJECT:
Receive the Second Quarterly Valenzuela/CAHSEE and Williams Settlement Uniform Complaints Quarterly Report for Period covering April 1, 2015,  through June 30, 2015, as required by EC 35186 (Williams Settlement Legislation SB550 and AB2727)
		 
BACKGROUND
As a result of the Williams Case (EC 35186), referred to as a landmark Superior Court case requires that every California public school provide each student with, at the very least, sufficient textbooks and instructional materials; clean, safe and functional buildings and facilities; and permanent, appropriately trained and assigned teachers.  Additionally, under the settlement of the Valenzuela / CAHSEE Settlement (EC 37254) students in grades 10 to 12, inclusive, shall be notified of services available to students up to two consecutive years after the completion of grade 12 who have not yet passed the CAHSEE.
		 
School districts shall support summarized data on the nature and resolution of all Williams Complaints and Valenzuela / CAHSEE Complaints on a quarterly basis to the governing board and the county superintendent of schools.  The report shall include the number of complaints by general subject area with the number of resolved and unresolved complaints.
		 
The attached report indicates the number of complaints, if any, filed from April 1, 2015, through June 30, 2015.
		 
FISCAL IMPACT
None
		 
FUNDING SOURCE
Senate Bill 6 (Williams)
State Instructional Materials Allocation
District Instructional Materials Budget
Other Categorical funds as Appropriate
		 
RECOMMENDATIONS
The Administration recommends that the Governing Board accept the Second Quarterly Valenzuela/CAHSEE and Williams Settlement Uniform Complaint Report for the period covering April 1, 2015, through June 30, 2015, as required by EC 35186 (Williams Settlement Legislation SB550 and AB2727).

SUBJECT:
Presentation and/or Discussion regarding Water Conservation Efforts
	 
	 
The management of water as a precious and vital resource is at the forefront of East Side's initiatives and behaviors.  For more than a decade, East Side Union High School District has been a leader in water conservation.
	 
The District's strategic approach to water conservation measures with proven results makes our program stand out, with achievement in environmental as well as economic responsibility.  In 2013, we were presented the Silicon Valley Water Conservation Award for Greenscape Management.  This award recognizes organization and individuals whose programs and leadership have advanced water conservation and recycled water us in Silicon Valley.
	 
The attached presentation provides information on historic and current water conservation measures, and the District's response to the critical drought conditions that the State is currently experiencing.

Item:  13.02
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, and Karen Poon, Director of Finance
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Adopt Resolution #2015/2016-02 Pertaining to the Education Protection Account (EPA)
	 
	 
The creation of the Education Protection Account (EPA) by Proposition 30, not only impacts cash flow patterns, but also has an accountability component.  Proposition 30 provides that all K-14 local agencies have the sole authority to determine how the funds received form the EPA are spent, but with these provisions:
	 
The spending plan must be approved by the Governing Board during a public meeting
EPA funds cannot be used for the salaries or benefits of administrators or any other administrative cost
Each year, the local agency must publish on its website an account of how much money was received from the EPA and how the funds were expended
	 
In addition, there will now be a requirement for the annual financial audit to include verification that the EPA funds were used as specified by Proposition 30.  If EPA funds are not expended in accordance with the requirements of Proposition 30, civil or criminal penalties could be incurred.
	 
District's Spending Plan:  All EPA funds received in 2012-13 and through 2018-19 will be used solely to support instruction and instructional-related services.
	 
As of the second principal apportionment for 2014-15, the District estimates to receive $36.9 million.  The District uses the EPA funds to pay teachers salaries and benefits.
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
General Fund
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the spending for Education Protection Account (EPA) and Adopt Resolution #2015/2016-02 Pertaining to the Education Protection Account (EPA).

EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT

TO:
Board of Trustees
								 
								 
FROM:
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
								 
								 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Linda da Silva, Director of Construction, Maintenance and Facilities, André Bell, Director of Purchasing and Capital Accounting, and Janice Unger, Capital Projects Purchasing Manager
								 
								 
SUBJECT:
Ratification of Bond/Capital Projects Contract(s) for Professional Services At or Below $50,000  
					 
					 
The attached lists the Bond/Capital Projects Contracts for Professional Services at or below $50,000 being recommended for Board ratification. 
					 
Fiscal Impact:
As indicated in the attachment
					 
Funding Source:
As indicated in the attachment
					 
Recommendation:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees ratify the Bond/Capital Projects Contract(s) for Professional Services at or below $50,000 as recommended in the attachment and authorization is being requested for the Superintendent and/or designee to execute amendments to the Agreement that may be needed during the term, provided such amendments do not: (i) extend the term of the contract; (ii) increase the price of goods or services provided under the contract by the greater of ten percent (10%) of the contract amount (based on the original contract amount exclusive of any approved amendments in the aggregate); or (iii) alter the quality or quantity of services or goods provided under the Board-approved contract per Board Policy 3312.1.
items.item_recommendation: It is recommended that the Board of Trustees ratify the Bond/Capital Projects Contract(s) for Professional Services at or below $50,000 as recommended in the attachment and authorization is being requested for the Superintendent and/or designee to execute amendments to the Agreement that may be needed during the term, provided such amendments do not: (i) extend the term of the contract; (ii) increase the price of goods or services provided under the contract by the greater of ten percent (10%) of the contract amount (based on the original contract amount exclusive of any approved amendments in the aggregate); or (iii) alter the quality or quantity of services or goods provided under the Board-approved contract per Board Policy 3312.1.
